questions.text: What is the stage of laryngeal carcinoma show:
questions.solution:
The staging of laryngeal carcinoma is determined based on the extent of the primary tumor (T), regional lymph node involvement (N), and the absence or presence of distant metastasis (M). In the TNM staging system:

T4aN1M0: This indicates a locally advanced tumor with the following Characteristics:

  • T4a: The tumor has invaded through the thyroid cartilage, which is a major structure in the larynx.
  • N1: Regional lymph nodes are involved, indicating spread to nearby lymph nodes.
  • M0: There is no evidence of distant metastasis.

questions.text: Given alongside is an image of tympanic membrane with retraction pocket what is the grade of the retraction pocket :
questions.solution:
• The answer is Grade II

Early grade II retraction

The Sade classification is a grading system for tympanic membrane retraction pockets. It is based on the extent of contact between the tympanic membrane and the middle ear structures.

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency with acute vertigo with horizontal nystagmus slow component is towards the left side what is more likely the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C: Left hypoactive labyrinth.

In the scenario described, the presence of acute vertigo with horizontal nystagmus, and the slow component of nystagmus being towards the left side, suggest dysfunction or hypofunction of the left labyrinth (inner ear). This condition is known as "Left hypoactive labyrinth." Labyrinth refers to the structures in the inner ear responsible for balance and spatial orientation.

KEY TAKEAWAY

  • Direction of nystagmus is always towards fast component.
  • In hypoactive labyrinth, nystagmus points towards opposite side.

questions.text:
Arrange in order from a cochlear nerve in the hearing pathway
A. Cochlear nucleus
B. Superior olivary nucleus
C. Medial geniculate
D. Inferior colliculus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of auditory pathway from the cochlear nerve in the hearing pathway is as follows:

  • A. Cochlear nerve: The auditory nerve (cochlear nerve) carries auditory information from the cochlea (the sensory organ of hearing) to the brainstem.
  • B. Cochlear nucleus: The cochlear nerve fibers synapse at the cochlear nucleus, which is located in the brainstem.
  • D. Superior olivary nucleus: After the cochlear nucleus, the auditory information ascends to the superior olivary nucleus, another structure in the brainstem.
  • C. Medial geniculate: From the superior olivary nucleus, the auditory pathway continues to the medial geniculate body, which is part of the thalamus.
  • From the medial geniculate body, auditory information is further relayed to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe of the brain for further processing and interpretation of sound.

The correct order is ABCD: Cochlear nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary nucleus → Medial geniculate.
